title: Different threads trying to access the same memory location participate in a
data race
i
if at least one of the operations is a modification (also known as
store operation
i
). These
data races
i
cause
undefined behavior
i
. To avoid them one needs to prevent these threads from concurrently executing such conflicting operations.

. To avoid them one needs to prevent these threads from concurrently executing such conflicting operations.

title: Synchronization primitives (mutex, critical section and the like) can guard such accesses. The Memory Model introduced in C++11 defines two new portable ways to synchronize access to memory in multi-threaded environment: atomic operations and fences.

inline_content.Text: Synchronization primitives (mutex, critical section and the like) can guard such accesses. The Memory Model introduced in C++11 defines two new portable ways to synchronize access to memory in multi-threaded environment: atomic operations and fences.

title: It is now possible to read and write to given memory location by the use of
atomic load
i
and
atomic store
i
operations. For convenience these are wrapped in the
std::atomic<t>
c
template class. This class wraps a value of type
t
c
but this time
loads
i
and
stores
i
to the object are atomic.

title: The template is not available for all types. Which types are available is implementation specific, but this usually includes most (or all) available integral types as well as pointer types. So that
std::atomic<unsigned>
c
and
std::atomic<std::vector<foo> *>
c
should be available, while
std::atomic<std::pair<bool,char>>
c
most probably wont be.

title: Atomic operations have the following properties:

inline_content.Text: Atomic operations have the following properties:

title: All atomic operations can be performed concurrently from multiple threads without causing undefined behavior.

inline_content.Text: All atomic operations can be performed concurrently from multiple threads without causing undefined behavior.

title: An
atomic load
i
will see either the initial value which the atomic object was constructed with, or the value written to it via some
atomic store
i
operation.

inline_content.Text: will see either the initial value which the atomic object was constructed with, or the value written to it via some

title: Atomic stores
i
to the same atomic object are ordered the same in all threads. If a thread has already seen the value of some
atomic store
i
operation, subsequent
atomic load
i
operations will see either the same value, or the value stored by subsequent
atomic store
i
operation.

title: Atomic read-modify-write
i
operations allow
atomic load
i
and
atomic store
i
to happen without other
atomic store
i
in between. For example one can atomically increment a counter from multiple threads, and no increment will be lost regardless of the contention between the threads.

inline_content.Text: in between. For example one can atomically increment a counter from multiple threads, and no increment will be lost regardless of the contention between the threads.

title: Atomic operations receive an optional
std::memory_order
c
parameter which defines what additional properties the operation has regarding other memory locations.

title: These memory order tags allow three different memory ordering disciplines:
sequential consistency
i
relaxed
i

release-acquire
i

i

inline_content.Text: These memory order tags allow three different memory ordering disciplines:

title: If no memory order is specified for an atomic operation, the order defaults to
sequential consistency
i
. This mode can also be explicitly selected by tagging the operation with
std::memory_order_seq_cst
c

inline_content.Text: If no memory order is specified for an atomic operation, the order defaults to
. This mode can also be explicitly selected by tagging the operation with

title: With this order no memory operation can cross the atomic operation. All memory operations sequenced before the atomic operation happen before the atomic operation and the atomic operation happens before all memory operations that are sequenced after it. This mode is probably the easiest one to reason about but it also leads to the greatest penalty to performance. It also prevents all compiler optimizations that might otherwise try to reorder operations past the atomic operation.

inline_content.Text: With this order no memory operation can cross the atomic operation. All memory operations sequenced before the atomic operation happen before the atomic operation and the atomic operation happens before all memory operations that are sequenced after it. This mode is probably the easiest one to reason about but it also leads to the greatest penalty to performance. It also prevents all compiler optimizations that might otherwise try to reorder operations past the atomic operation.

title: The opposite to
sequential consistency
i
is the
relaxed
i
memory ordering. It is selected with the
std::memory_order_relaxed
c
tag. Relaxed atomic operation will impose no restrictions on other memory operations. The only effect that remains, is that the operation is itself still atomic.

atomic store-release
i

(or
load-consume

title: Fences also allow memory operations to be ordered between threads. A fence is either a release fence or acquire fence.

inline_content.Text: Fences also allow memory operations to be ordered between threads. A fence is either a release fence or acquire fence.

title: If a release fence happens before an acquire fence, then stores sequenced before the release fence are visible to loads sequenced after the acquire fence. To guarantee that the release fence happens before the acquire fence one may use other synchronization primitives including relaxed atomic operations.

inline_content.Text: If a release fence happens before an acquire fence, then stores sequenced before the release fence are visible to loads sequenced after the acquire fence. To guarantee that the release fence happens before the acquire fence one may use other synchronization primitives including relaxed atomic operations.
